Title: the gorilla experiment

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Raj are playing a racing game on the Wii.
Penny: Hey, Leonard, check this out. (Throws some food in the air and catches it in her mouth)
You want me to put it back?
Oh, come on, it’s fine. We’ll just put it all on the table, you know, family style.
Oh, yeah, you can’t sit there.

Oh no, no, you see, in the winter, that seat is close enough to the radiator so that he’s warm, yet not so close that he sweats. In the summer, it’s directly in the path of a cross-breeze created by opening windows there and there. It faces the television at an angle that isn’t direct, so he can still talk to everybody, yet not so wide that the picture looks distorted.
Oh, thanks. They are cute, aren’t they?
Shoes for Less.
Oh, great selection, great prices.
Womenfolk?
Just eat your dinner.
Yeah, well, I don’t think it’s very funny.
Howard, never let her go.
It’s not about shoes.
Um, actually, can we do it in private?
Thanks, Raj. Okay, so here’s the thing, I was wondering if you could maybe teach me a little physics?
Yeah, okay, cool. I don’t need the PBS special, I just want to know enough so I can talk to Leonard about his job. You know, like Bernadette does.
‘Cause I want to surprise him.
Come on, Sheldon, this is important to me.
You’re sitting here playing video games all day.
Sure. I did the one with the frogs.
Yeah, actually, it was pretty cool. A lot of the girls threw up, but I gutted that thing like a deer.
Oh, come on! A smart guy like you, it’ll be a challenge. You can make it like an experiment.
Great! It’s a little insulting, but great. I’ll be KoKo.
Hey, Sheldon.
Ready to get started?
Um, I don’t have one.
I have to take notes?
There’s gonna be a test?
Thank you.
Ancient Greece?
Um, does this have anything to do with Leonard’s work?
Twenty six hundred years?
I have to go to the bathroom.
Not for twenty six hundred years.
Uh, we know that… Newton was a really smart cookie. Oh! Is that where Fig Newtons come from?
Sorry.
I don’t know.
Hey! You don’t have to be so mean!
No, you just suck at teaching.
Oh, God, Sheldon, look I’m trying to understand, but you’re going too fast. Can you just back up a little bit?
Not that far back!
I don’t know. Where were we looking up at the night sky?
Damn it!
Squared?
Aristotle?
Five?
Then I don’t know.
Because I’m stupid!
Okay, look, can we just please forget about all this extra stuff and can you just tell me what Leonard does?
Really? That’s it? Well, that doesn’t sound so complicated.
Okay, I just have one question. What exactly are sub-atomic particles?
Thank you.
Oh, balls.

Actually, that’s not true, Leonard. In fact, recently I’ve been thinking that given the parameters of your experiment, the transport of electrons through the aperture the nano-fabricated metal rings is qualitatively no different than the experiment already conducted in the Netherlands. Their observed phase shift in the diffusing electrons inside the metal ring already conclusively demonstrated the electric analogue of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum-interference effect. That’s it. That’s all I know. Oh, wait! Fig Newtons were named after a town in Massachusetts, not the scientist.
Sheldon: Leonard, she’s doing it again.
No. It upsets Sheldon when she willy-nilly takes it from the containers without regard for its equitable distribution. This is essentially why you have famine in India.
Leonard.
Hello.
Wait, no, that’s a false equivalency. More does not equal merry. If there were 2,000 people in this apartment right now, would we be celebrating? No, we’d be suffocating.
Don’t Sheldon me. We ordered for five people, not six.
Oh, sure. And while we’re at it, why don’t we put our hands behind our backs, have an old-fashioned eating contest?
Perhaps there’s hope for you after all.
My mother was right. Hell is real.

Yes. Leonard’s work is nearly as amazing as third graders growing lima beans in wet paper towels. (Raj whispers to him) While I appreciate the oh, snap, I’m uncomfortable having your moist breath in my ear.
Howard?
Your shoes are delightful. Where did you get them?
Bazinga. I don’t care.
That’s not fair. I got stuck behind a tree.
Just need a little more practice.
It’s not about shoes, is it? I don’t think I could go through that again.
Then speak.
All right. (To Raj) Go away. I agree, it’s rude, but she asked for privacy.
A little physics? There’s no such thing. Physics encompasses the entire universe, from quantum particles to supernovas, from spinning electrons to spinning galaxies.
Why can’t Leonard teach you?
Can’t you surprise him in some other way? For example, I’m sure he’d be delightfully taken aback if you cleaned your apartment.
Penny, this would be a massive undertaking, and my time is both limited and valuable.
Okay, point. What sort of foundation do you have? Did you take any science classes in school?
The one with the frogs.
I’m sorry, Penny, I don’t think so.
Interesting. I suppose if someone could teach sign language to KoKo the gorilla, I could teach you some rudimentary physics.
Not likely. KoKo learned to understand over 2,000 words, not one of which had anything to do with shoes.
Research journal, entry one. I’m about to embark on one of the great challenges of my scientific career, teaching Penny physics. I’m calling it Project Gorilla.
Come in. Take a seat. Subject has arrived. I’ve extended a friendly casual greeting.
One moment. Subject appears well-rested and enthusiastic. Apparently, ignorance is bliss. All right, let us begin. Where’s your notebook?
How are you going to take notes without a notebook?
How else are you gonna study for the tests?
Tests. Here. It’s college-ruled. I hope that’s not too intimidating.

You’re welcome. Now, Introduction to Physics. What is physics? Physics comes from the ancient Greek word physika. It’s at this point that you’ll want to start taking notes. Physika means the science of natural things. And it is there, in ancient Greece, that our story begins.

Hush. If you have questions, raise your hand. It’s a warm summer evening, circa 600 BC, you’ve finished your shopping at the local market, or agora, and you look up at the night sky. There you notice some of the stars seem to move, so you name them planetes, or wanderer. Yes, Penny?

This is the beginning of a twenty six hundred year journey we’re going to take together from the ancient Greeks through Isaac Newton to Niels Bohr to Erwin Schrodinger to the Dutch researchers that Leonard is currently ripping off.
Yeah, give or take. As I was saying, it’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece… Yes, Penny?
Can’t you hold it?
Project Gorilla, entry two. I am exhausted.

Now, remember, Newton realized that Aristotle was wrong and force was not necessary to maintain motion. So let’s plug in our 9.8 meters per second squared as A and we get force, Earth gravity, equals mass times 9.8 meters per second per second. So we can see that MA equals MG and what do we know from this?
No, Fig Newtons are named after a small town in Massachusetts. Don’t write that down!
Now, if MA equals MG what does that imply?
How can you not know? I just told you. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?
I’m sorry. (Smiling) Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?
Really? Of those two explanations, which one seems the most likely?
All right. It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…
Okay! At what point did you begin to feel lost?
Greece.
There’s no need to get frustrated, people learn at different rates. Unlike objects falling in a vacuum, which…? MA equals MG?
No.
No.
Oh!
Why are you crying?
That’s no reason to cry. One cries because one is sad. For example, I cry because others are stupid and it makes me sad.
All right. Leonard is attempting to learn why sub-atomic particles move the way they do.
It’s not. That’s why Leonard does it.
A good question.
And to answer it, we first must ask ourselves, what is physics?
It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…
Leonard: I think it upsets Sheldon when you play with the food.
It upsets Sheldon when you play with the Sheldon.
Yeah. Hey.
Sure. The more, the merrier.
Sheldon…
Relax, it’ll be fine, sit down, you guys.
That’s where Sheldon sits.
I am. Are you interested in physics?
Actually, my tests of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum interference effect have reached an interesting point. Right now, we’re testing the phase shift due to an electric potential.
Yes, I am. You want to see a simulation on my laptop?
Hey, look, it’s Howard and his girlfriend Bernadette.
Yeah, no, I got it.
Ah, terrific. We’re getting the electron accelerator set up. We should be ready to go day after tomorrow.
You’re welcome to come.
Excuse me?
Yeah? So?
What are you talking about?
Has it ever worked?
Howard, relax, I’m not interested in your girlfriend.
I believe you.
What did I do now?
What?
You do have a problem with her hanging out with me.
What was I supposed to tell her?
And what would that be?
You told her my experiment was stupid?
Should I, um, leave you two alone?
Okay, good, ’cause I wasn’t really gonna go.
We’re shocked.
Or loud noises, clowns and nuns.
He had a panic attack once when he got his head stuck in a sweater.
I don’t know. Maybe because I’m crazy?
It’s up to you. He didn’t call your experiment stupid.
Tushy face, that is going on Twitter right now.
I’m glad you enjoyed it. Most people aren’t that interested in what I do.
Howard (arriving): What’s up, my nerdizzles? Raj, Sheldon, I want you to meet my girlfriend Bernadette.
Howard: Leonard, Penny, you know my girlfriend Bernadette.
Bernadette, say fo’shizzle to my nerdizzles.
I hope it’s all right, I told my girlfriend Bernadette she could join us for dinner.
Come on, Sheldon. let the womenfolk chat.
Gals? Chicks? Utero-Americans?
Yeah?
What?
Hey, fellas. This is my girlfriend Bernadette. My girlfriend Bernadette.
Have no idea. Hey, Leonard.
Thought I’d give the little woman a tour of the old salt mines.
Like Hanukkah in July.
No.
Could you grab me another napkin, sweetie?
Thanks, honey. (She goes) All right, what is your deal?
Inviting my girlfriend to come see your electron accelerator?
Wow! You really are a piece of work. It’s not enough you get the prom queen, you have to get the head of the decorating committee, too?
Don’t play innocent with me. I practically invented using fancy lab equipment to seduce women.
Not so far, but that’s not the point!
I hope not, because you don’t want to mess with me. I’m crazy.
Huh?
Oh, that explains a lot.
Of course.
That’s great, Ma!
No, no, don’t move. Hey, Ma, can I have lamb stew for dinner?
Please? I got a real hankering.
Thanks, Ma.
Always Le Seur peas with lamb stew!
Then get the regular!
Sorry about that.
I’m already on vibrate.
Uh, what do you mean?
Really? He said that?
Me? No. I may have mentioned that it’s a little inappropriate to be asking another man’s girlfriend to his experiment without first discussing it with said man.
I didn’t say anything like that. I said Leonard has to ask my permission. (Bernadette storms out) Come on, I don’t want to eat lamb stew with my mother. Damn, I was this close on the bra.
Okay, I got a bone to pick with you.
I was in bed with Bernadette, and you text-blocked me.
We were completely naked, about to devour each other when, you text her that I have a problem with her hanging out with you.
Yeah, but that’s not what you tell her.
I don’t know, something that doesn’t make me come off as a petty, jealous douche.
Come on, do I have to think of everything?
Hi.
Same thing you’re doing here. I came to see Leonard’s experiment.
I was just repeating what Sheldon said. Let’s not get off topic, Bernadette, I need to apologize. I was wrong to tell you who you should be friends with.
Look, I know I come off as confident and worldly, but the truth is I’m not.
Which is why I tend to feel threatened by other guys.
But I now realize how foolish that is.
It was a full turtleneck. Why aren’t you helping me?
Bernadette, please, I’m asking you to give me another chance.
Bernadette: I don’t think I can. I don’t have Howard’s street cred.
What?
Why not?
He can’t sit somewhere else?
Ooh, I love your shoes.
Where’d you get them?
I’ve been meaning to go over there.
Don’t take him too seriously, a lot of what he says is intended as humour.
Me neither, but he just lights up when I laugh.
So, Leonard, Howard says you’re working on fundamental tests of quantum mechanics.
Oh, I find it fascinating. If I hadn’t gone into microbiology, I probably would have gone into physics. Or ice dancing.
That’s amazing.
Are you going to try to set up the voltages using tunnel junctions?
Oh, yeah, show me. In microbiology, the most exciting thing I get to work with is yeast.
Who are all those people?
Hi.
He doesn’t mean salt mines. He means where he works.
So, how’s your experiment going?
Boy, I’d love to see that.
Really? Oh, that’d be great. How exciting is that?
Do they have that?
Oh. You got me again. This isn’t non-fat yogurt, this is fatty fat fat. Excuse me.
Sure.
Howard?
It unhooks in the front.
I guess I should go.
You know, that one I got. Howard, did you say something to Leonard about me?
He says if I go see his experiment tomorrow it might weird you out.
You’re not jealous of Leonard, are you?
Are you saying I need to ask your permission to hang out with Leonard?
Hey, Leonard. Am I too late to see the experiment? Oh, hi.
What are you doing here?
No, you didn’t. You said Leonard’s experiment was stupid.
No, Leonard, you should hear this.
What do you think, Leonard? Should I give him another chance?
Come here, tushy face.
Raj, you should’ve seen Leonard’s experiment. The interference pattern was so cool when the electron beam was on.
Raj: Ha! Eat my dust, racially stereotypical plumber.
And a cow and a penguin. Face it dude, whether it’s a real car or a virtual cartoon car, you can’t drive.
What you need is cheat codes, motor skills and a magic genie who grants wishes to little boys who suck at Mario Kart.
Penny (knocking and entering): Hey, Sheldon, can I talk to you for a second?
Howard\u2019s Mother: Senior fitness was cancelled. It turns out you can forget how to ride a bike. I’m fine, but, oy, did Sam Harpootian eat gravel.
What’s great about an 80-year-old Armenian man with half his chin scraped off?
Lamb stew? I’d have to go to the supermarket.
Oh, I can’t say no to my little tushy face. I’ll be back soon.
Do you want the regular peas or the Le Seur?
You’re right! When you’re right, you’re right! What if they’re out of the Le Seur?
All right! You don’t have to yell!
Bernadette (her phone chimes): Let me just put that on vibrate.

It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…
Okay, I got a bone to pick with you.
I was in bed with Bernadette, and you text-blocked me.

What was I supposed to tell her?

Should I, um, leave you two alone?
No, Leonard, you should hear this.
Okay, good, ’cause I wasn’t really gonna go.
